para.paratext: When applicable, a witness may claim personal privilege in refusing to answer a question. When a witness invokes a privilege, the court must determine if the witness is entitled to the privilege and whether the testimony sought falls within the subject matter for which the privilege applies. The party seeking to establish the privilege has the burden of proving it applies to the testimony at issue.[1]

Some privileges apply to particular relationships and others apply to particular kinds of information. A witness may not refuse to answer a question by claiming that the answer is inadmissible,[2] but must clearly invoke a privilege that he is entitled to claim.

Generally, only that person entitled to a privilege may invoke it,[3] and it is immaterial whether he is a party to the case in which privileged testimony is sought. The reverse of the claim of a privilege is waiver of privilege. Only the person entitled to a privilege may waive it, and no other person can object to the waiver.

Unlike evidence subject to an evidentiary exclusion, an opposing party does not have the right to object to the admission of privileged communications. Only the person vested with the outside interest or relationship fostered by the privilege may object to its admission.[4]

Many privileges arise from relationships deemed to have such value that any communications made within the scope of the relationship must not be subject to disclosure in a legal setting.[5] Wigmore recognized four fundamental conditions necessary to the establishment of such a privilege:
The communications must originate in a confidence that they will not be disclosed.
This element of confidentiality must be essential to the full and satisfactory maintenance of the relation between the parties.
The relation must be one which in the opinion of the community ought to be sedulously fostered.
The injury that would inure to the relation by the disclosure of the communications must be greater than the benefit thereby gained for the correct disposal of litigation.[6]

Because the invocation of privilege necessarily shuts out evidence that may be relevant, the scope of a privilege should be construed narrowly.[7] The United States Supreme Court stated in Trammel v. U.S. that privileges should be “construed and accepted only to the very limited extent that permitting a refusal to testify or excluding relevant evidence has a public good transcending the normally predominant principle of utilizing all rational means for ascertaining truth.”[8]

There are three general areas of privilege discussed herein: privileges arising from confidential relationships, governmental privileges,[9] and constitutional privileges. Each type of privilege is based upon the concept that there are certain interests or values whose protection is more important than the harm done by withholding the evidence.

Unlike Georgia's Evidence Code, the Federal Rules of Evidence do not create statutory privileges. Enacted in 1974, Fed. R. Evid. 501 provides that, in federal cases, the courts are to interpret the principles of the common law as it relates to privileged communications “in the light of reason and experience.” In cases involving diversity jurisdiction, state law should be applied.[10]

Except as otherwise required by the Constitution of the United states or provided by act of Congress or in rules prescribed by the Supreme Court pursuant to statutory authority, the privilege of a witness, person, government, state, or political subdivision thereof shall be governed by the principles of the common law as they may be interpreted by the courts of the United States in the light of reason and experience. However, in civil actions and proceedings, with respect to an element of a claim or defense as to which state law supplies the rule of decision, the privilege of a witness, person, government, state, or political subdivision thereof shall be determined in accordance with state law.[11] In Trammel v. U.S., the United States Supreme Court said, “In … enacting Rule 501, Congress manifested an affirmative intention not to freeze the law of privilege. Its purpose rather was to ‘provide the courts with the flexibility to develop rules of privilege on a case-by-case basis’ … and leave the door open to change.”[12] Federal courts, however, have been reluctant to create new privileges.[13]

Although the federal rules do not provide for any statutorily recognized privileges arising from confidential relationships, they do provide for the fluid recognition of such privileges by federal courts from common law as reason and experience dictate. Like Georgia, federal courts have recognized and applied privileges for confidential communications between spouses, attorney and client, mental health professional and patient, and clergy. Federal and Georgia courts have been unwilling to recognize privileges for other types of relationships such as between a journalist and the person interviewed.[14]

It should also be noted that there are many statutes which make certain governmental information and reports privileged. In each instance, the statutes create a privilege or a qualified privilege for certain information and reports in governmental files. These privileges, for the most part, have received very little judicial consideration. See, e.g., O.C.G.A. § 48-5-314 (county tax assessors); O.C.G.A. § 42-5-36 (certain inmate files); O.C.G.A. § 49-5-40 (child abuse/neglect or reports of substance abuse by children); O.C.G.A. § 31-7-143 (certain medical review committees).
